case_name: Bangalore Woollen, Cotton and Silk Mills Ltd. v. Kuppuswamy

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1851 of 1967 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1851 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the award dated

facts.text: Appeal from award dated October 9, 1967 of Labour Court, Bangalore in Reference No. 86 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: from the award dated October 9, 1967 of the Labour Court, Bangalore in Reference No. 86 of 1966. P. Malhotra and D. N. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Dispute referred: whether Management of Bangalore Woollen, Cotton and Silk Mills Ltd. justified in terminating services of five workmen including Kuppuswamy.

anchor.surface_text: where the dispute referred for adjudication was, whether the Management of the Bangalore Woollen, Cotton and Silk Mills Ltd.  here in after referred to as the Company  was justified in terminating the services of five workmen including one Kuppuswamy?.

facts.text: Binny Mills Labour Association entered settlement with management, agreed to reinstate Ramanadha, gave up demand for three others excluding Kuppuswamy.

anchor.surface_text: During the companyrse of the proceedings the Binny Mills Labour Association, Bengal, a registered trade union, sponsoring the cause of the dismissed workmen entered into a settlement with the management whereby the management agreed to reinstate one Ramanadha and gave up its demand for reinstatement of three others excluding Kuppuswamy.

facts.text: Union withdrew support to Kuppuswamy from date of settlement; Kuppuswamy conducted own case before Labour Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Union however withdrew its support to Kuppuswamy from the date of the settlement and the latter stated before the Labour Court that he would companyduct his own case.

facts.text: Kuppuswamy alleged to have behaved insolently towards Warehouse Master on 3rd November 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The facts relating to the dismissal of Kuppuswamy are as follows. He is alleged to have behaved in an insolent manner towards the Warehouse Master, his superior officer, on 3rd November, 1963

facts.text: Charge sheet issued to Kuppuswamy on 6th November 1963 for misconduct under Standing Order No. 13(ii).

anchor.surface_text: in respect whereof he was given a charge sheet on 6th November, 1963 the companyplaint against him being that he was guilty of misconduct falling under Standing Order No. 13 11  i.e. act subversive to discipline.

facts.text: Kuppuswamy submitted written explanation on 8th November 1963.

anchor.surface_text: He submitted a written explanation on 8th November.

facts.text: Enquiry held by Mill Manager on 10th November 1963.

anchor.surface_text: An enquiry was held by the Mill Manager on 10th November

facts.text: Mill Manager found charge proved, terminated Kuppuswamy's services on 10th November 1963.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day the Mill Manager came to the companyclusion that the charge against Kuppuswamy had been proved and taking into account the gravity of the misconduct and his past companyduct the Mill Manager found him number a fit person to remain in the employment of the companypany and terminated his services.

facts.text: Before Labour Court: Kuppuswamy filed statement of claim, management statement of objections, rejoinder by Kuppuswamy.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Labour Court Kuppuswamy filed his statement of claim, the management its statement of objections followed by a rejoinder of Kuppuswamy.

facts.text: Labour Court accepted finding of guilt but set aside termination due to no opportunity to challenge Veeraraghavan's statement on past record.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court while accepting the finding of the domestic tribunal that Kuppuswamy was guilty of the misconduct alleged against him was number inclined to retain the order of termination of his service mainly on the ground that he was number given an opportunity to challenge the statement of one Veeraraghavan regarding his past record of service

facts.text: Charge: on 3rd November 1963 at 9.15 a.m., Kuppuswamy shouted at Warehouse Master Veeraraghavan, created disorderly scene.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against Kuppuswamy formulated by the manager was that on the 3rd of this month at about 9.15 a.m. Kuppuswamy had behaved in tan insolent manner towards the Warehouse Master, Mr. Veeraraghavan by shouting at him and creating a disorderly scene in the Warehouse office.

facts.text: Veeraraghavan stated Kuppuswamy disregarded instructions by stacking pieces obstructing passage, shouted 'You do number find out our difficulty... Are we number human beings?'

anchor.surface_text: According to Veeraraghavans statement, Kuppuswamy had disregarded the instructions given to him by one Allam, Assistant Manager by stacking the pieces between the examiners in a manner which would obstruct the free passage for the examiners and that he did so deliberately. Kuppuswamy when produced before the Warehouse Master by Allam is alleged to have Pared up and shouted at him saying You do number find out our difficulty. You do number listen to our grievances. He is further alleged to have shouted at the top of his voice You think we are all slaves ? You do number know how to treat us. Are we number human beings ?

facts.text: Kuppuswamy did not cross-examine witnesses or call witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Kuppuswamy was asked whether he wanted to call anyone as witness and Kuppuswamy answered in the negative. ... Asked whether he had any questions to put to Veeraraghavan, Kuppuswamy answered in the negative

facts.text: Veeraraghavan stated Kuppuswamy absent without leave multiple times, similar behaviour a month back, no action due to intercession.

anchor.surface_text: Veeraraghavan to give his remarks about Kuppuswamys companyduct and ability and any other relevant information in respect of the respondent whereupon Veeraraghavan stated that Kuppuswamy had been absent without leave or permission on a number of occasions and that about a month back he had behaved in a manner similar to the one with which he was charged but numberdisciplinary action had been taken against him on the intercession of one Rajagopal.

facts.text: Enquiry officer did not give Kuppuswamy opportunity to question or explain Veeraraghavan's statement on past record.

anchor.surface_text: The Manager did number ask Kuppuswamy on this occasion as to whether he wanted to put any question to Veeraraghavan on the further testimony given by him or whether he had any explanation to offer.

facts.text: Termination order considered past absences, sick leave, prior insolence.

anchor.surface_text: While looking into your service records, I find that you are educated up to S.S.L.C. ... you had been warned by him for absence for 3 days without leave or permission and that you had availed within a span of about 6 months, 25 days sick leave No 9. Much more than all of these, he had let you off only a month earlier for behaving insolently towards him

facts.text: Supreme Court held enquiry violated natural justice due to no opportunity on past record.

anchor.surface_text: the record made by the enquiry officer amply demonstrates that Kuppuswamy was number given a chance to crossexamine Veeraraghavan on his further statement number was he asked to state anything by way of explanation. To our mind the record ,of the enquiry officer seems to suggest that he was under the impression that he companyld look into the past record of the delinquent without affording him an opportunity of explanation or testing by cross-examination what was alleged against him.

facts.text: Termination based on cumulative effect of current misconduct and past lapses.

anchor.surface_text: The language of the order leaves numberdoubt in our mind that it was the cumulative effect of the lapses on the part of the respondent that had resulted in the order of termination of service.

facts.text: Government previously refused reference in 1964 and 1965 for Kuppuswamy's case.

anchor.surface_text: The letter of the Under Secretary to Government, Labour Department dated August 17, 1964 ... The second letter ,is dated August 21, 1965

facts.text: Settlement memorandum dated 24th June 1967: Union withdrew cases for others, management reinstated Ramanatha only.

anchor.surface_text: The memorandum of settlement under section 12 3  of the Industrial Disputes Act which was put in on the 24th June1967

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Labour Court's order of reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is, whether on the facts and circum- stances of the case, the Labour Court was justified in exercising its discretion in ordering reinstatement

issues.text: whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Labour Court was justified in exercising its discretion in ordering reinstatement specially when he himself had recorded in the course of his award that he accepted the finding that Kuppuswamy was guilty of the misconduct alleged against him in the charge sheet

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is, whether on the facts and circum- stances of the case, the Labour Court was justified in exercising its discretion in ordering reinstatement specially when he himself had recorded in the course of his award that he accepted the finding that Kuppuswamy was guilty of the misconduct alleged against, him in the charge sheet.

issues.text: Whether the Labour Court had gone wrong in setting aside the order of dismissal on the ground which was not put forward by the workman himself, specially because he never asked for an opportunity to cross-examine Veeraraghavan on his last statement and had never taken the point that he had been denied an opportunity to explain what was put forward against him by Veeraraghavan in his last statement before the enquiry officer

anchor.surface_text: The points urged before us were as follows The Labour Court had gone wrong in setting aside the order of dismissal on the ground which was number put forward by the workman himself, specially because lie never asked for an opportunity to cross-examine Veeraraghavan on his last statement and bad never taken the point that he had been denied an opportunity to explain what was put forward against him by Veeraraghavan in his last statement before the enquiry officer.

anchor.surface_text: In our view that principle can have numberapplication to the facts of this case. Although the enquiry officer found in fact that the respondent had behaved insolently towards the Warehouse Master, he did number companye to the companyclusion that this act of indiscipline on a solitary occasion, was suffi- cient to warrant an order of dismissal.

holdings.text: The domestic enquiry violated principles of natural justice because Kuppuswamy was not given opportunity to cross-examine Veeraraghavan on his statement regarding past record or to offer explanation thereon.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry officer routinely offered cross-examination opportunities on main charge but omitted for past record statement despite its adverse impact; record shows officer's impression that past record needed no explanation, violating audi alteram partem.

holdings.text: The termination order cannot be sustained solely on the main charge of misconduct as it was based on the cumulative effect of the proved misconduct and untested past lapses.

anchor.surface_text: The language of the order leaves numberdoubt in our mind that it was the cumulative effect of the lapses on the part of the respondent that had resulted in the order of termination of service. It was number a case where two separate charges had been framed against the delinquent and they were of such a serious nature that the finding of guilt on any one would warrant the dismissal of the delinquent,from service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order explicitly considers past absences, sick leave, and prior insolence alongside current misconduct; solitary act deemed insufficient for dismissal; precedents like Railway Board distinguished as involving severable serious charges.

holdings.text: The order of reference under s.10(1) IDA is valid; prior refusals by Government do not invalidate a later reference based on fresh opinion that industrial dispute exists.

anchor.surface_text: The submission that the order of reference is invalid as the Government had numbergrounds, or material to form the, opinion about the existence of a dispute in order to enable it to make an, order under s. 10 1  is one which does number merit any companysideration. In the absence of the Government from the array of the parties it is number possible to, companye to any finding as to whether there were any such material or number.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10(1) permits reference anytime on Government's opinion; no material before court to question; prior letters show context change possible without bar.

holdings.text: The referred industrial dispute does not cease merely because the union withdraws support for one workman and settles others.

anchor.surface_text: We do number however see any reason to hold that the dispute which had already been referred by Government should cease to be one in respect of a portion of it merely because the Union did number choose to represent the case of a particular dismissed employee. If there was an industrial dispute at the time of references it would number cease, to be one merely because the claim of some of the dismissed employees was settled by mutual agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settlement under s.12(3) affects only settled claims; reference covers the dispute as made; s.2A unnecessary to consider.

holdings.text: Mere lapse of time between dismissal and reference does not justify denying reinstatement absent evidence of dislocation.

anchor.surface_text: If mere lapse of time be enough to lead the Industrial Tribunal to hold that there should be numberreinstatement of service the power of reinstatement will become obsolete. In any case the Management must try to show that reinstatement will cause dislocation of work and the Tribunal must take that into companysideration. In this case we find numbersuch companypelling circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delays inherent in process; no dislocation shown for single workman in large industry; Shalimar Works distinguished as involving mass reinstatement.

holdings.text: Labour Court justified in ordering reinstatement despite accepted guilt on serious misconduct, as no loss of confidence alleged by management and enquiry vitiated.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry invalid on natural justice; no loss of confidence claim; discretion proper per precedents like Hindustan Steels; proportionality favors reinstatement.

holdings.text: DCGM v. Kalu Ram is distinguishable and does not support that workman's failure to request opportunity excuses violation.

anchor.surface_text: According to this Court If the respondent did number ask for an opportunity to cross-examine the appellants expert with the help of an expert because he- had numberlegal advice, that default on his part cannot mean that the enquiry officer violated the principles of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts differ: no request refusal there, but here officer aware and omitted proactive offer on past record unlike main charge.

holdings.text: Reinstatement appropriate absent management allegation of lost confidence.

anchor.surface_text: It has become almost a settled principle that reinstatement should be awarded where the management justifiably alleges that they have ceased to have companyfidence in the dismissed employee. In other cases the Tribunal must companysider carefully the circumstances of the case to companye to a finding that justice and fairplay require that reinstatement should be awarded. In this case, there is numberallegation that the Management had lost companyfidence in Kuppuswamy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled principle; no such allegation here; doubt if dismissal without past record.
